title: Democrats recruit speakers to testify against fusion voting
text:
The apparent drive to drum up opposition to fusion voting comes as the topic has overtaken much of the public debate over the commission’s work. | AP Photo/Mark Lennihan Democrats recruit speakers to testify against fusion voting

ALBANY — Democrats are actively recruiting people to attend the Public Finance Reform Commission’s meeting in Albany on Wednesday to speak out against fusion voting.

An email from Albany County Democratic Chair Jack Flynn sent to ward leaders on Monday noted that state Democratic chairman Jay Jacobs would be in Albany for a meeting of the commission, on which he serves.

Story Continued Below

In the email, a copy of which POLITICO obtained, Flynn wrote in reference to Jacobs: “He is asking if anyone would Like to speak tomorrow about reasons to eliminate fusion voting. There is a meeting at Rockefeller institute on State st, where he sits on a panel. It starts at 10am."

Flynn then asked for responses from the ward leaders. "If you don’t respond," he wrote, "I am taking you off of any further emails as there are many who never respond which I consider very inappropriate as a ward leader/town chair.”

The apparent drive to drum up opposition to fusion voting comes as the topic has overtaken much of the public debate over the commission’s work and will do little to tamp down the suspicions of critics who believe the commission is out to kill the practice.

One county committee member said they were subsequently approached by their local leader about the public hearing. Another received an email from their local leader on Tuesday. It read: “The State Chair of the Democratic Party, Jay Jacobs, has contacted our County Chair, Jack Flynn and requested that committee members speak against fusion voting."

Flynn did not respond to a request for comment late Tuesday afternoon.

Jacobs is from Long Island, where the ties between fusion and patronage have led to more widespread criticism than in other parts of the state. Jacobs has opposed the practice in the past, although after being appointed to the commission by Gov. Andrew Cuomo, he said he would approach the subject with “an open mind."

Asked about the emails, Jacobs said he had been contacted by “a couple of chairs” who were interested in attending. Since “the folks who have been in favor of fusion voting have been there,” he said he encouraged them to participate.

“I certainly would encourage anybody that shows up to speak their mind,” he said. “There are a lot of people who are opposed to fusion voting … If that’s the way it is, don’t keep it a secret. We need a full and open discussion of the issues.”

At a public hearing in Manhattan last Tuesday, the Working Families Party and its supporters brought scores of individuals who used some of the three minutes they were allotted to telling the commissioners to keep their hands off fusion. They recruited so many backers that the room was filled to capacity, forcing many attendees to watch on a television screen set up in the hallway. The hearing went on for nearly four hours, with only a scattered few attendees speaking against the practice.

The WFP and other groups have similarly been working to drum up attendance for Wednesday's meeting, which will be held in much smaller rooms utilized by the Rockefeller Institute.
description: The move won't tamp down suspicions about the commission's work.
